Isn’t writing weird? It’s like you think things and then they’re on the page and then other people read them in their heads. Low key fan of alliteration.
Jan 11

The Definitive Ranking of the “Good Player, Bad Team” Players in the NBA

Sometimes you can be a Carmelo Anthony marooned in the annals of New York City watching your management display various levels of incompetence. Sometimes you’re rookie Brandon Jennings on the Bucks.

For all the trouble the NBA and NBA media go through when handing out awards, there really isn’t enough recognition for the best Good Players on a Bad Team (patent pending). Think about it, ESPN is quick to make you aware when it’s the first time LeBron James ever scored 15 points in a 2nd quarter during a winter solstice with mercury in retrograde when a fan in section 102, row 15 seat 3 drank exactly 3.31 beers, but forget to get to the bottom of who has had the benefit of having their statistical production enhanced by the sole fact that they happen to be playing on a team composed purely of “he’s still in the NBA?” players.

Good thing about identifying a disservice is that you are then plainly aware of its existence and can take steps A through Z, with a slight detour at M, to correct the apparent universal “wronging.” As such, I would like to take this time to rank the players on bad teams on the “Good Player, Bad Team” scale that has been carefully put together specifically for this purpose. For science.

So what does it mean to be a good player on a bad team? The answer to this, like the answers to all good questions asked between 1 and 3 am, when you should be sleeping instead of reading the Wikipedia page on thermonuclear dynamics, is complicated. But also simple. But also complicated. Allow me to explain.

To be a Good Player on a Bad Team, you have to display the statistical prowess similar to that of a good player. This means highs in one of the valued statistical categories, the big three so to speak (rebounds, points and assists). However, your statistical production has to come not only from your skill, but also from the fact that you’re playing on a team that is full of basketball players only in name and the next best option to you is Tim, the season ticket holder from section 105. You have to be conceptually terrifying to opposing teams, but only in as far as there isn’t anyone else to guard.

The sure way to test a how Good Player Bad Team a player is is to put him on a team with another good player. Are they now racing towards the Playoffs? Do they still manage to put out the statistical output that they’ve been known for? Have they forever altered the fabric of the NBA existence by combining forces? If the answer is no, then you have yourself a Good Player on a Bad Team. If the answer is yes, then you simply have uncovered a good player among the factory of sadness that is the fringes of the Association. Allow me to elaborate.

Carmelo Anthony on New York is a good player. He has consistently been a top scorer and terrified teams. However, when paired with good enough players he’s been able to bring his team into the playoffs and at least give them an illusion of competitiveness. You can easily imagine Carmelo Anthony on a team with other good players and making that team a contender while maintaining his own level of production. Carmelo Anthony is a good player.

Rookie Brandon Jennings has taken the League by storm through a combination of an absence of f**ks and a knack for scoring a basketball. He pushed the Bucks to the playoffs — still his biggest achievement to date. Following that, Jennings moved around, has been paired with better players and failed to induce the same kind of fear in opposing teams as he did in his first year in Milwaukee. He never matched his statistical outputs or pushed another franchise into a brief pocket of historical relevance (aka the Playoffs). Brandon Jennings is an average player. He is however, when on a bad team, is a Good Player Bad Team player.

So what is a good criteria to judge Good Player, Bad Team players in the NBA.

Is he statistically a good player: Are the stats that he puts up every night similar to those of players we consider to be in the upper echelon of the NBA? (out of 10 points)

Is he on a bad team: is the team out of or barely in the Playoff picture? (out of 10 points)

Has he been on a better team before and what was his statistical output: Has the player in question ever been on a team with other good players and if so was his statistical average similar to what we’re seeing now? How did his presence affect the team? *Reverse Grading (the better the team was with him the less points). (out of 10 points)

What happens to this player’s production when put on another team with good players: Does it stay the same? Does it plummet? Do we now consider the new team a true contender or at least a step closer to contending? For the sake of this experiment we will identify team X as the Boston Celtics, a good team with good players and a determined system which took in a good player this summer, got better and allowed said good player to maintain his statistical presence. *reverse grading. (out of 10 points)

Jimmy Butler (Chicago Bulls)

Is he statistically a good player: Jimmy Butler is statistically a good player. He is averaging 25 points, 6.7 rebounds, 4.6 assists and 1.7 steals per game. Those are good stats. Those may actually be All-Star Stats. He is an elite performer and an is considered top five all around at his position. He gets full points. (10 points)

Is he on a bad team: The Chicago Bulls are a bad team with an allergic reaction to long-distance shooting and reasonable team composition. They are either barely in or barely out of the Playoff race. They have however deceived the League into thinking they’re a good team for a small period of time and have consistently convinced the Toronto Raptors that they’re a good team. So they get points deducted. (5 points)

Has he been on a better team before and what was his statistical output: Jimmy Butler has played on good teams before. Factually he never played on a team that had a less than .500 record. That makes his record here very good and his score very low. What’s more, he has consistently put up solid stats indicative of a good player. (2 points)

What happens to this player’s production when put on another team with good players: I can picture Jimmy Butler on Boston. I once pictured Jimmy Butler on Boston and as someone from Toronto and thus, by law and national mandate, a Toronto Raptors fan I couldn’t sleep for 3 days. Jimmy Butler would be really good on the Celtics. (1 point)

Total: 18/40

(Maybe) NBA Coaches Should Just Coach
The NBA dual role of Coaching & working the Front Office is in trend. Should it really be in vogue?16winsaring.com

Andre Drummond (Detroit Pistons)

Is he statistically a good player: That depends. While lacking in some categories, Drummond is an elite rebounder, supposedly making him a good player. He is lacking in a few other categories but has been a linchpin of the current Detroit team. (7 points)

Is he on a bad team: The Detroit Pistons have made playoffs only once with Drummond and beyond one valiant display of exemplary wall-building haven’t really had much to show for it. They’re a bad team. (8 points)

Has he been on a better team before and what was his statistical output: Andre Drummond has never been on a good team. The best he can say is he has been on an average team. (8 points)

What happens to this player’s production when put on another team with good players: I can see Andre Drummond becoming a specialist when on another team. He is the kind of “very good at this one thing that makes you wonder how is he even human” good at rebound, but not exceptional at anything else. Drummond needs a surrounding to be effective. He could be a good fit on a good team, however his statistical averages would dip from that of a good player. (5 points)

Total: 28/40

Carmelo Anthony (New York Knicks)

Is he statistically a good player: Anthony is an exceptional player who is a generational talent lauded for his scoring prowess among the NBA. (10 points)

Is he on a bad team: The New York Knicks are less a basketball team and more of a factory of sadness. (10 points)

Has he been on a better team before and what was his statistical output: He has played on playoff teams including the said Knicks and the Denver Nuggets. In all cases he was still the best player on those teams, almost solely responsible for their success. (0 points)

What happens to this player’s production when put on another team with good players: Let me paint you a word picture: Carmelo Anthony — Olympian MVP. (0 points)

Total: 20/40

Serge Ibaka (Orlando Magic)

Is he statistically a good player: A consistent starter, Serge Ibaka has been one break out season away from becoming a really good player for four seasons now. He is still a good, do-it-all option for the team without stats that would warrant me giving Serge Ibaka the amount of money someone is going to give Serge Ibaka this summer. (7 points)

Is he on a bad team: The Orlando Magic are most certainly a bad team and have a history of being a bad team (10 points).

Has he been on a better team before and what was his statistical output: Serge Ibaka has famously been on the Oklahoma City Thunder, but has never fully displayed a significant shift for either himself or the Thunder as a team. (8 points)

What happens to this player’s production when put on another team with good players: Decisive consensus is that putting Serge Ibaka on a good team would squarely maintain the status of Serge Ibaka as Serge Ibaka. He is a known quantity that may experience a slight stat dip but would otherwise slide into the role of a role player much like you would slide into a worn in pair of sweatpants. (7 points)

Total: 32/40

Joel Embiid (Philadelphia 76ers)

Is he statistically a good player: You should be ashamed for even contemplating the act of asking this question. (10 points)

Is he on a bad team: 10 points

Has he been on a better team before and what was his statistical output: He has never been on a better team. Like an a whale at Sea World, this is the only world Joel has ever known. He does however get a statistical consideration because this is his first year on said bad team and they’ve already improved their record from last year and he is playing on a minutes restriction. (0 points)

What happens to this player’s production when put on another team with good players: That team becomes a contender. Joel Embiid wins the MVP. The world explodes into a million pieces creating a dozen of alternative universes where Joel Embiid remains the only constant. (0 points)

Total: 20/40

It Doesn’t End Well
Even for the best, NBA careers don’t end well.16winsaring.com

Hassan Whiteside (Miami Heat)

Is he statistically a good player: Last year Whiteside matched the block output of multiple teams on his own. That’s the kind of production only Voltron was capable of and only when all five paragons where in total sync. One person was off and the whole lion’s head was dead in the ground. This year he’s matching a career high in points but also rebounding 14 rebounds per game and getting 2.2 blocks per game. Those are elite stats in case you were wondering (one of them is even bold on Basketball Reference for added effect). (10 points)

Is he on a bad team: The 2016/17 Miami Heat are the byproduct of Pat Riley making the deal with the devil some time ago and the devil coming to collect in an unceremonious fashion. (10 points)

Has he been on a better team before and what was his statistical output: Whiteside has been a member of the Playoff Miami Heat that managed to not only get to the second round against all odds, but also trouble the Toronto Raptors enough to earn him a very fat and juicy contract extension. However, much like a lot of his career, that felt as if it was happening in spite of Whiteside who was consistently more interested in generating his own buckets and his 2k rating than anything else. (7 points)

What happens to this player’s production when put on another team with good players: Every ancient city needed a city guard, an elite group of men that would barricade the entire place behind their backs and fight off Zeus if necessary. While it’s difficult to see Hassan Whiteside’s ego having enough puzzle edges necessary to fit into a team right away, with enough change, he is the kind of big that would make a slash and dish point-guard heavy system viable and competitive. (6 points)

Total: 33/40

Brook Lopez (Brooklyn Nets)

Is he statistically a good player: Meh. Brook Lopez is the peanut butter and jam sandwich among NBA big men: satisfying and necessary in the moment but instantly forgettable in place of other and better options. (7 points)

Is he on a bad team: I still haven’t found any proof that the Barkley’s Center was built on an ancient Native American burial site, but for lack of better explanations that is my default stance on things. (10 points).

Has he been on a better team before and what was his statistical output: It’s with great difficulty of speaking that anyone would ever in their right presence of mind classify the 2013/14 Brooklyn Nets as good in any kind of way except maybe on paper. Even then, not the kind of fancy paper you print resumes and Shea Serrano tweets on. Average A4 found in any print shop around the country for like 2 cents a pop. (7 points)

What happens to this player’s production when put on another team with good players: It’s hard for me to imagine Brook Lopez being any kind of productive in any kind of environment outside of the one he is in. He doesn’t do enough positional center stuff centers in the NBA are supposed to be good at (5.1rpg ya’ll) and overall gives off the air of a decisively average NBA player at best. (9 points)

Total: 33/40

Damian Lillard (Portland Trail Blazers)

Is he statistically a good player: Dame is what happens when you drink dry ice before you’re supposed to drink dry ice. (8 points)

Is he on a bad team: Following last season’s act that had more twists than the final third of The Prestige, the concept of defense and cohesive rotations was introduced to the Trail Blazers. The Trail Blazers refused to acknowledge the introduction. (8 points)

Has he been on a better team before and what was his statistical output: Dame Dolla played on a team that missed the playoffs only once his entire career and following that season he also had the top WS on the Blazers. Despite everyone always waiting for him to taper off his ascend, Lillard has consistently proven to be elite. (4 points)

What happens to this player’s production when put on another team with good players: Surrounded by a strong system and a set of players who have not only heard of defending, but are able to execute it on a somewhat fundamental level, Lillard could be a capable leader. (3 points)

Total: 23/40

DeMarcus Cousins (Sacramento Kings)

Is he statistically a good player: I will fight you. (10 points)

Is he on a bad team: I occasionally cry when I think of the Sacramento Kings’ draft history following their very astute selection of Boogie Cousins. (10 points)

Has he been on a better team before and what was his statistical output: Cousins has consistently remained the sole shining light in Sacramento. He has taken up the mantle, pulled sword form stone and delivered many a battle ground speech in his charge to lead the Kings to the promise land. Unfortunately, happiness does not exist in Vivekland. I am however giving him consideration for his year in Kentucky. (5 points)

What happens to this player’s production when put on another team with good players: On a team with management that is able to calculate the probability of drafting Nik Stauskas ahead of literally anyone else in that round, up until Bruno Caboclo, DeMarcus Cousins becomes the winged messenger of the basketball Apocalypse. (0 points)

Total: 25/40

Anthony Davis (New Orleans Pelicans)

Is he statistically a good player: Sometimes I wonder if Anthony Davis’ stat lines indicate that he is playing basketball or trying to solve complex mathematical equations and we just can’t comprehend it. (10 points)

Is he on a bad team: I would classify the New Orleans Pelicans as fundamentally un-luckly. They’re unlucky in a cartoonish way where you toss a boomerang and it flies across the whole world hitting you in the back while you wait for you to come back from the front. In a way that you’ll probably have a lengthy phone conversation with the ACME Quality Control department. (7 points)

Has he been on a better team before and what was his statistical output: Anthony Davis has played on a playoff team and has once defeated Cthulhu in a game of one-on-one at the buzzer by triple clutching a three. (4 points)

What happens to this player’s production when put on another team with good players: Picturing Anthony Davis on literally any team in the playoff picture currently in the NBA is basically an elaborate sadomasochism exercise. (0 points)

Total: 21/40

The NBA’s One of a Kind Most Valuable Player Race
We’ve been given the best MVP Race in the modern era. A slew of candidates, worthy winners in most other seasons — but…16winsaring.com

Danilo Gallinari (Denver Nuggets)

Is he statistically a good player: Gallinari has consistently had the benefit of playing on teams ran “by committee” without a standout performer. As such, no one player in particular ever broke through the mold, Gallo being no exception. (5 points)

Is he on a bad team: The Denver Nuggets aren’t as much bad as they are confused. The higher the altitude the thinner the air the more oxygen your brain requires to process subsequent series of actions. That is a purely scientific explanation of why it’s taking the Denver Nuggets so long to figure out the next direction for its franchise. (7 points)

Has he been on a better team before and what was his statistical output: Gallo is a very serviceable by committee guy. Consistently stuck in the same situation on different teams his level of production never had to fluctuate out of the norm. (5 points)

What happens to this player’s production when put on another team with good players: Given an appropriate system Gallo’s production normalizes not far from where he is now with added efficiency and resembling that of a player staying firmly in his lane. (5 points)

Total: 22/40

Coach Dude Luke Walton (LA Lakers)

Is he statistically a good player (coach): The only notable exception on this list. The Lakers are running the team by committee and their notable best member is Coach Dude Luke Walton who brought his love of scented candles, organic kombucha and motion offense back to LA in the wake of earth scorched by Byron Scott. The Lakers have improved across the board in all team categories at a staggering rate. (7 points)

Is he on a bad team: Through pain and tears, the Lakers are currently a bad team. A fun team, but a bad team. (8 points)

Has he been on a better team before and what was his statistical output: Luke Walton oversaw some of the best basketball on the planet during his interim as the Warriors Head Coach, facing off reporters and criticisms that his success was simply due to his team. Given the rating improvements across the board in Los Angeles and presumably his introduction of an all-locally grown diet to the team Coach Dude Luke Walton effect is no fluke and can be carried over to better teams. (5 points)

What happens to this player’s production when put on another team with good players: Conference Finals? Finals? A national wide advertising deal with Whole Foods? Sky is the limit. (2 points)

Total: 23/40

Karl Anthony Towns (Minnesota Timberwolves)

Is he statistically a good player: It must be difficult to be Andrew Wiggins. To witness yourself become the savior of the franchise and then almost immediately the supplementary sidekick to the actual savior of the franchise who is more a live version of 2K create a player with stats maxed out than a real life person. (8 points)

Is he on a bad team: They’re a young team and that has to count for something. (6 points)

Has he been on a better team before and what was his statistical output: Outside of his brief tenure in the retractable house that John Calipari built at Kentucky, KAT has not been on a serious contender in the NBA. That being said, he is the fundamental first brick in the building of a serious contender in the NBA. (4 points)

What happens to this player’s production when put on another team with good players: What happens when the Mighty Morphin’ Power Rangers finally decided that individually they can’t defeat whatever mythical foe they’re against and decide to summon the Dinozord? (2 points)

Total: 20/40

Eric Bledsoe (Phoenix Suns)

Is he statistically a good player: Remember when car companies decided to fit the capabilities of a truck into a smaller car and called it an SUV? That’s kind of what we have here except instead of a truck it’s LeBron James and instead of a SUV it’s Eric Bledsoe. Despite the constant state of flux in Phoenix and the management’s inability to stop experimenting with the back-court composition Bledsoe has been a consistent performer in multiple categories. (8 points)

Is he on a bad team: The Suns are yet to make the playoffs with Bledose on the roster, however by the same token, Bledsoe has only played one full season that has not been derailed by injury. It was a pretty good season. (7 points)

Has he been on a better team before and what was his statistical output: Prior to arriving in Phoenix, Bledsoe spent time marooned behind the greatest point guard of this generation, fighting for scraps of playing time. His statistical variance in that situation was less of a case of not being able to pull his weight and more so lacking the opportunity to do so. (5 points)

What happens to this player’s production when put on another team with good players: With an improving shot and the ability to deliver across multiple categories, Eric Bledose could be a vital part of a contender team given the right trade for the Phoenix Suns. (5 points)

Total: 25/40

The NBA CBA: Explaining The Designated Player Veteran Extension and “Choice”
Wondering about some of the new ins & outs of the new CBA? Cole Zwicker makes his Sixteen Debut explaining some.16winsaring.com

Harrison Barnes (Dallas Mavericks)

Is he statistically a good player: In the first season Barnes is allowed to write his own story (presumably with the same ink he almost penned his agent’s suicide note last spring) he is seeing statistical outputs across the board and leading the Dallas Mavericks exactly nowhere, although in retrospect that may just be a byproduct of Marc Cuban’s inability to generate appropriate interest in anyone joining the Mavs. (8 points)

Is he on a bad team: At some point Rick Carlisle ran out of his magic potion and the Mavs crashed back to Earth. (10 points)

Has he been on a better team before and what was his statistical output: Yes, yes he has. And he possibly cost them an entire NBA championship. This is the one unique situation where we are able to have a direct one year difference comparison. Barnes has been usurped by Kevin Durant in the Golden State line-up of inevitable death and suffering and Durant has been posting increased stats across the board (potentially also mailing them to Barnes monthly via UPS). (8 points)

What happens to this player’s production when put on another team with good players: I’m not clairvoyant and I do not own a time machine, but statistical evidence points to a steady regression when inserted into a unit of better or similar basketball talent. (8 points)

Total: 34/40

Final Result

Based on statistical evidence, accurate NBA analysis verified by absolutely no-one but myself. Harrison Barnes is the quintessential “Good Player, Bad Team” player in the NBA — a shining paragon of the statistical effects playing for a bad team can have on an average player.

Current Top “Good Player, Bad Team” Player in the NBA: Harrison Barnes
